facts.text: Appeal arises from a judgment of the High Court of Hyderabad under article 374(4) of the Constitution of India, Civil Appeal No. 189 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from a judgment of the High Court of Hyderabad under article 374  4  of the Constitution of India Civil Appeal No. 189 of 1950.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1950 October 12 by KHALILUZZAMAN J.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. October 12. The judgment of the Court was delivered by KHALILUZZAMAN J.--This appeal arises out of execu- tion proceedings.

facts.text: Appellant Kapurchand had a money decree against Mir Hamid Ali Khan, husband of respondent Mst. Kaderunnissa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Kapurchand, had a money decree, amongst others, against one Mir Hamid Ali Khan, husband of the respondent Mst. Kaderunnissa.

facts.text: In execution of the decree, the house in dispute belonging to the deceased judgment-debtor was attached.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of the decree the house in dispute belonging to the deceased judgment-debtor was attached.

facts.text: Widow of deceased raised objection to attachment on ground she was in possession in lieu of outstanding dower.

anchor.surface_text: To the attachment the widow of the deceased raised an objection on the ground that she was in possession of it in lieu of her outstanding dower and companyld number be dispossessed till her claim was satisfied.

facts.text: Executing court allowed the objection and ordered house sold subject to respondent's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The objection was allowed by the executing companyrt and it was ordered that the house be sold subject to the respondents claim, the decree-holder being entitled to the surplus, if any, out of the sale proceeds.

facts.text: Executing court viewed widow's dower claim has priority over unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: There was number much possibil- ity of the house fetching more in the execution sale than the amount due on account of dower. The companyrt took the view that the widows claim for dower had priority over the debts due to other unsecured creditors

facts.text: Decree-holder applied in revision to High Court, without success.

anchor.surface_text: The decree holder made an application in revision to the High Court but without any success.

facts.text: Decree-holder preferred appeal to Judicial Committee of the State.

anchor.surface_text: He then preferred an appeal to the Judicial Com- mittee of the State and it is number before us under article 374  4  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Husband died leaving the house in dispute and outstanding debts including to decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: It is companyceded that the husband died leaving the house in dispute and leaving outstanding a number of debts including the one due to the decree-holder.

facts.text: House was not charged or mortgaged by husband to wife or creditors.

anchor.surface_text: The house was number charged or mortgaged by him either in favour of his wife or in favour of any of the creditors.

facts.text: Widow in possession of husband's estate in lieu of dower claim with consent of other heirs or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: the sole point ... is wheth- er a widow in possession of her husbands estate in lieu of her claim for dower with the companysent of the other heirs or otherwise

facts.text: High Court dismissed revision application of decree-holder.

anchor.surface_text: The decree holder made an application in revision to the High Court but without any success. He then preferred an appeal

facts.text: Court holds widow's dower claim has no priority over unsecured creditors.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is in the nature of an unsecured debt

facts.text: Executing court ordered sale subject to widow's claim, decree-holder to surplus if any.

anchor.surface_text: it was ordered that the house be sold subject to the respondents claim, the decree-holder being entitled to the surplus, if any, out of the sale proceeds. There was number much possibil- ity

facts.text: Appeal allowed, judgments below set aside, executing court to sell property and distribute proceeds rateably.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow this appeal, set aside the judgments of the two companyrts below and direct the execut- ing companyrt to proceed with the execution in accordance with the observations made herein.

facts.text: Widow's objection had no substance.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the objection raised by the widow had numbersubstance in it and the executing companyrt should have directed the property

facts.text: Abdul Wahid Owasi appeared for appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Wahid Owasi, for the appellant. Ahmed Saeed Khan, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Ahmed Saeed Khan appeared for respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Ahmed Saeed Khan, for respondent No. 1. 1950. October 12.

facts.text: House unlikely to fetch more than dower amount in execution sale.

anchor.surface_text: There was number much possibil- ity of the house fetching more in the execution sale than the amount due on account of dower.
under article 374  4  of the Constitution of India Civil Appeal No. 189 of 1950.

concepts.unlisted_description: Basis for appeal from Hyderabad High Court to Judicial Committee

anchor.surface_text: under article 374  4  of the Constitution.

The sole point for determination in the appeal is wheth- er a widow in possession of her husbands estate in lieu of her claim for dower with the companysent of the other heirs or otherwise is entitled to priority as against his other unsecured creditors.

concepts.interpretation: Widow not entitled to priority over unsecured creditors

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: l. 29, Kitabul- faiaiz, page 137, it is pointed out that payment of debts has priority over bequests

concepts.unlisted_label: Widow's Priority for Dower over Unsecured Creditors
concepts.unlisted_description: Under Muslim law, widow in possession for dower has no priority against unsecured creditors

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is in the nature of an unsecured debt and she has numberpriority of any kind against the other unsecured creditors of her husband.

concepts.interpretation: Dower is an unsecured debt ranking equally with other debts unless secured by husband

concepts.unlisted_description: Dower claim treated as unsecured debt without priority unless created by husband's act

concepts.interpretation: Dower debt has priority over heirs' claims but not other creditors

concepts.unlisted_description: Under Muslim law, dower ranks before distribution to heirs

anchor.surface_text: In the administration of the estate of a deceased Muslim the rule laid down by early text writers and Fatwas, such as Fatwa-e-Alamgiri, is that in the first instance the funeral expenses of the deceased should be paid out of the estate and that having been done, the estate should be divided between the legatees and the heirs after payment of the debts due from him.

concepts.interpretation: Order: funeral expenses, then debts (including dower), then legatees/heirs; no priority among debts

concepts.unlisted_description: Funeral expenses first, then all debts, then bequests and heirs

concepts.unlisted_description: Proceeds of execution sale to be distributed pari passu among unsecured creditors

If the husband had created any charge in favour of his wife in lieu of her claim for dower, then it cannot be doubted that she would have priority over the unsecured creditors.

concepts.interpretation: Only if husband creates charge/mortgage does widow become secured creditor with priority

concepts.unlisted_description: Priority only for secured claims created by debtor; dower otherwise unsecured

anchor.surface_text: The dower of a Muslim woman is a settlement in her favour made prior to the marriage companytract and is similar to the donatio propier nuptias of the Romans but is of such an obligatory nature that if it is number mentioned before or at the time of the marriage, it is presumed to exist to the extent of a proper dower amount.

concepts.interpretation: Dower is a contractual obligation akin to marriage settlement for consideration, treated as debt

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: of a proper dower amount. Among the Hebrews the dower settled on a wife was for her use after the termination of marriage and among the Jews marriages

concepts.unlisted_description: Obligatory marriage settlement/debt in Muslim law

arguments.claim: Unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is an unsecured debt with no priority against other unsecured creditors

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that unless the husband by his own act has placed the widow in a better position than his other creditors, her claim for dower is in the nature of an unsecured debt and she has numberpriority of any kind against the other unsecured creditors

arguments.claim: Quranic text in Surai-Nissa enjoins payment of dower in preference to bequests and inheritance but is silent on priority over other creditors

anchor.surface_text: The Quranic text in Surai-Nissa, Ruku 4, enjoins the payment of dower in preference to bequests and inheritance but it is silent on the question of priority of dower debt in relation to other creditors.

arguments.claim: In administration of Muslim estate, first funeral expenses, then all debts paid, then legatees and heirs; no priority indicated for dower over other unsecured creditors

anchor.surface_text: In the administration of the estate of a deceased Muslim the rule laid down by early text writers and Fatwas, such as Fatwa-e-Alamgiri, is that in the first instance the funeral expenses of the deceased should be paid out of the estate and that having been done, the estate should be divided between the legatees

arguments.claim: Dower is a contractual debt with consideration, having preference over bequests and inheritance but no priority over other contractual debts

anchor.surface_text: The dower of a Muslim woman is a settlement in her favour made prior to the marriage companytract and is similar to the donatio propier nuptias of the Romans but is of such an obligatory nature that if it is number mentioned before or at the time of the marriage, it is presumed to exist to the extent of a proper dower amount.

arguments.claim: Judicial consensus holds that widow's dower ranks pari passu with other unsecured creditors, no priority; distinguishing contrary decisions

anchor.surface_text: In Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty  1  a Bench of the Madras High Court held that a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is number a preferential charge on the estate.

arguments.court_reasoning: the consensus of authority is against the proposition that a widow as an unsecured creditor has any priority over the other unsecured creditors

arguments.claim: The widow's objection had no substance; property to be sold and proceeds distributed rateably amongst decree-holders and the widow

arguments.claim: Reference to Surai-Nissa text enjoining payment of wife's claim and favourable treatment to widows does not give absolute protection against other claims

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dower treated as unsecured debt under Muslim law unless secured by husband's act; supported by texts, fatwas, and judicial consensus distinguishing from priority over heirs

holdings.text: A widow by her lien does not have any priority over other creditors; Mehr as a debt has priority over other heirs claim to have the estate distributed among themselves. These two considerations are not affected by the fact of her being in or out of possession of the estate

anchor.surface_text: A widow by her lien does number have any priority over other creditors  2  Mehr as a debt has priority over other heirs claim to have the estate distributed among themselves. These two companysiderations are number affected by the fact of her being in or out of posses- sion of the estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Tyabji's Muhammadan Law statement; possession does not elevate lien to priority over creditors

holdings.text: In the administration of the estate of a deceased Muslim the rule laid down by early text writers and Fatwas, such as Fatwa-e-Alamgiri, is that in the first instance the funeral expenses of the deceased should be paid out of the estate and that having been done, the estate should be divided between the legatees and the heirs after payment of the debts due from him

anchor.surface_text: In the administration of the estate of a deceased Muslim the rule laid down by early text writers and Fatwas, such as Fatwa-e-Alamgiri, is that in the first instance the funeral expenses of the deceased should be paid out of the estate and that having been done, the estate should be divided between the legatees and the heirs after payment of the debts due from him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All debts paid before legatees/heirs with no specified priority among debts; Quran silent on dower vs other creditors

holdings.text: dower ranks as a debt and the widow is entitled along with other creditors to have it satisfied out of the estate and that her right is not greater than that of any other creditor

anchor.surface_text: In Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty  1  a Bench of the Madras High Court held that a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is number a preferential charge on the estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial consensus (Madras, PC, Allahabad except two cases, Mulla) holds dower pari passu with other unsecured debts; disapproves contrary views

holdings.text: the objection raised by the widow had no substance in it and the executing court should have directed the property to be sold and the sale proceeds distributed rateably amongst the decreeholders and the widow

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the objection raised by the widow had numbersubstance in it and the executing companyrt should have directed the property to be sold and the sale proceeds distributed rateably amongst the decreeholders and the widow.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above principles to facts: widow unsecured, no priority despite possession; rateable distribution required

holdings.text: the above mentioned two Allahabad decisions do not lay down the law correctly on this point and the rule has been correctly laid down in Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the above men- tioned two Allahabad decisions do number lay down the law companyrectly on this point and the rule has been companyrectly laid down in Ameer Amreal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overrules specific precedents inconsistent with consensus

holdings.text: we allow this appeal, set aside the judgments of the two courts below and direct the executing court to proceed with the execution in accordance with the observations made herein

anchor.surface_text: In the result we allow this appeal, set aside the judgments of the two companyrts below and direct the execut- ing companyrt to proceed with the execution in accordance with the observations made herein.

anchor.surface_text: Ameer Ammal v. Sankaranarayanan Chetty  1  a Bench of the Madras High Court held that a claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is number a preferential charge on the estate.

precedents.cited_proposition: claim for unpaid dower constitutes a debt payable pari passu with the demands of other creditors and is not a preferential charge on the estate

precedents.citation: Maina Bibi v. Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad  2

anchor.surface_text: Maina Bibi v. Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad  2  it was held that where the widow is number in the position of a se- cured creditor and is otherwise in possession of the hus- bands estate with the companysent of the heirs, she is entitled

precedents.case_name: Maina Bibi v Chaudhri Vakil Ahmad
precedents.cited_proposition: widow not secured creditor but entitled to retain possession of estate with consent of heirs until dower satisfied

precedents.citation: Meer Meher Ally v. Mst. Amanee  3

anchor.surface_text: Meer Meher Ally v. Mst. Amanee  3  it was held that the lien of the widow over the property in her possession is number a lien in the ordinary legal sense of the term and that a claim for dower is in the same position as that of any other ordinary creditor

precedents.case_name: Meer Meher Ally v Mst Amanee
precedents.cited_proposition: widow's lien not ordinary lien, dower claim ranks pari passu with other ordinary creditors

anchor.surface_text: Maina Bibi v. Wasi Ahmad  4  it was held that she has numberright of possession against the creditors, number being a secured creditor herself. At page 547 the following observations occur - she cannot set up any such right of possession against creditors

precedents.cited_proposition: widow has no right of possession against creditors as not secured creditor
precedents.cited_holding: she cannot set up any such right of possession against creditors claiming to have the debts owing to them from the husband satisfied out of the estate

anchor.surface_text: Hamira Bibi v. Zubaida Bibi  1  it was observed that dower ranks as a debt and the wife is entitled along with the other creditors to have it satisfied on the death of the husband out of his estate. Her right, however, is numbergreater than that of any other unsecured creditor.

precedents.cited_proposition: dower ranks as a debt, wife entitled along with other creditors, right not greater than other unsecured creditor

precedents.citation: Imtiaz Begum v. Abdul Karim Khan  ,2

anchor.surface_text: Imtiaz Begum v. Abdul Karim Khan  ,2  the same view was expressed. In para. 295 Mr. Mulla in his book on Muhammadan Law has adopted the view that dower ranks as a debt and that the widow is entitled along with other creditors

precedents.case_name: Imtiaz Begum v Abdul Karim Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: dower ranks as debt without greater right than other creditors

precedents.citation: Kulsum Bibi v. Shiam Sunder Lal  3

anchor.surface_text: Kulsum Bibi v. Shiam Sunder Lal  3 , in which it was held that a widow in possession of her husbands estate is entitled as against the other heirs of her husband and as against the creditors to retain posses- sion until her dower is satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Kulsum Bibi v Shiam Sunder Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: widow in possession entitled against heirs and creditors to retain possession until dower satisfied

precedents.citation: Mst. Ghafooran v. Ram Chandra Das  4

precedents.case_name: Mst Ghafooran v Ram Chandra Das
precedents.cited_proposition: widow's possession cannot be disturbed till dower debt satisfied

anchor.surface_text: Mohamed Turabuddin v. Yasin Begum  5  a Bench. of the Hyderabad High Court held that the claim of a widow for dower was in the nature of a secured debt. There was numberother creditor in that case which arose between the heirs and the widow.

precedents.cited_proposition: claim of widow for dower in nature of secured debt

anchor.surface_text: Wahidunnissa Begum v. Yasin Begum  6  it was pointed out that the claim of the widow for dower does number create any interest or charge on the property and that the position of a widow is number only that of a creditor where her dower remains unpaid but also of an heir.

precedents.cited_proposition: widow's dower claim does not create interest or charge on property, position as creditor and heir

anchor.surface_text: In the administration of the estate of a deceased Muslim the rule laid down by early text writers and Fatwas, such as Fatwa-e-Alamgiri, is that in the first instance the funeral expenses of the deceased should be paid out of the estate and that having been done, the estate should be divided between the legatees and the heirs after payment of the debts due from him.

In the result we allow this appeal, set aside the judgments of the two companyrts below and direct the execut- ing companyrt to proceed with the execution in accordance with the observations made herein.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we hold that the objection raised by the widow had numbersubstance in it and the executing companyrt should have directed the property to be sold and the sale proceeds distributed rateably amongst the decreeholders and the widow.
